column2: An Islamic poet, in search of a new host, has showed up at your court. His time spent among the courts of France has gifted him with court knowledge, and by all accounts he is skilled with words. We may have use of him.

An Islamic steward, in search of a new host, has showed up at your court. Well versed in the way of coin from his time in Bordeaux, there is no denying his administrative capability. He would make a fine steward.
An Islamic scholar, fleeing persecution elsewhere near France, has showed up at your court. His time spent abroad in the libraries of the ancient university have made him a great and wise teacher.

An Islamic courtier, fleeing persecution elsewhere near France, has showed up at your court. He seems to know a lot about you, even things that you do not necessarily want others to know, which is impressive for a man you have never met. We may have use of him.

An Islamic musician, in search of a new host, has showed up at your court. Combining the famous melodies of the France with traditional Islamic nasheeds, his music is unlike anything you have ever heard before. We may have use of him.

An Islamic courtier, fleeing persecution elsewhere near France, has showed up at your court. His time spent treating and caring for his community has earned him a respectable career as a physician among his community.
An Islamic general, in search of a new host, has showed up at your court. Providing to you a valuable insight to the ancient Regiment Trainings of the the ancient Jannisary Order.
A Muslim Courtier of much talent joins you...

An Islamic physician, in search of a new host, has showed up at your court. He is well versed in Islamic theories of medicine, but his community has expelled him for reasons he refuses to elaborate on. We may have use of him.

After much discussion and debate by the ulama, his Magnificence, [d_naqshbandi.Holder.GetTitledFirstName] has been conviced that it is time to declare another era of great conquests, as in the days of the first Caliphs. The Dar al-Islam must grow again. All righteous Naqshbandi men should prepare to join the ranks of the ghazi for the upcoming struggles. This signals a new era of Naqshbandi expansion.

The Holy city of Istanbul, where the great Sultans ruled the Sublime State of old, has fallen to infidels! His Magnificence, [d_naqshbandi.Holder.GetTitledFirstName] will not let this stand, and has declared that another era of great conquests is upon us, as in the days of the first Caliphs. The Dar al-Islam must be defended! All righteous Naqshbandi men should prepare to join the ranks of the ghazi for the upcoming struggles. This signals a new era of Naqshbandi expansion.

A mighty empire has arisen in Anatolia, as was in the days of old. In light of these fortunate tidings, his Magnificence, [d_naqshbandi.Holder.GetTitledFirstName] has been conviced that it is time to declare another era of great conquests, as in the days of the first Caliphs. The Dar al-Islam must grow again. All righteous Naqshbandi men should prepare to join the ranks of the ghazi for the upcoming struggles. This signals a new era of Naqshbandi expansion.

With the core of the Islamic world firmly under your control, and the representatives of the various Sunni movements formed after the time of the Disaster at your table, you begin. You give a long argument why the world fell into the chaos it did - largely in part because there was no defender of the faith - and make a passionate plea that, together, the Sunni faithful would survive better than divided by innovations and beset by polytheists, idolaters, and those who do not worship God. Slowly, the council turns in your favor, the Grand Mufti nods in agreements first, and reccomends you take the mantle of Caliph. By the end of the meeting, a landmark event has happened, as most of the Sunni faithful now recognize the unity of the People of the Prophet's Tradition once more.

Every Pious Muslim must at least complete the Hajj to the Great City of [c_mecca.GetName] once in the thier life. Home to the myriad of important activities whose traditions have existed since the ancient times before the Event. As you embark on this journey, you can't help but watch your home fade into the distance, stately matters can wait, for you are have higher things to attend to.

The Islamic World is a wide and diverse place. Having a rich history of blessed shrines, mosque and other features that can be just as important as the conducting the Hajj to [c_mecca.GetName]. Whether it be for shrines of the Walis or the dedications to the Prophet Muhammad, his family and companions, as a pious Muslim you may visit these blessed places anytime...
To the City of Yusuf and Musa, I go!
To the Blessed City of the Prophet, I go!
To the City of the Martyrs, I go!

Whilst Mecca and Medina hold great religious significance to all pious Muslims, there are plenty of other sites to visit. Al-Aqsa is particularly for its location in the city of al-Quds, the Holy city of Yusuf and Musa.
Whilst Mecca may be the more blessed city, there are plenty of other sites to visit. Such as the City of the Prophet, Al Madinah and the resting place of his companions and family, Al-Baqi'.

Whilst Mecca and Medina hold the greatest religious significance to all Muslims, there are plenty of other sites to visit. For the faithful of Ahlus-Sunnah, the Great Mosque of Damascus built by the Umayyad Caliphs is one such site.
All are equal in front of God!

The city of al-Quds is the location of a great holy site to the [Root.Religion.GetName] faith. The silver-domed mosque of al-Aqsa was built by the noble caliph Umar ibn al-Khattab, whose successors have tirelessly expanded the magnificent complex that you behold. al-Quds in general is regarded often as the third most blessed city of all of Islam, and home to the Haram al-Sharif a raised platform that is revered by all people of the Book. The blessed lands this mosque was built upon remained according to legends miraculously unscathed by the Event, and to this millions of devotees continue to pray in its ancient halls.
A Blessed Trip to Al Madinah

The City of the Prophet Muhammad (SAWS) the last prophet of God Almighty. The city of Al Madinah is a popular location for pious Muslims to contemplate on the life of the prophet. Away from bustles of the city proper is the hallowed grounds of Al-Baqi' believed to be the final resting place for many of Muhammad's relatives and companions. A somber reminder of his sacrifices for the LORD.
May we live as he did, pious and true!

The City of the Caliphs of the Umayyad Caliphate, of Salahuddin, and of all other heroes from time immemorial. The famed masjid, standing tall and proud in the face of the Disaster and the faithful of the city are always pleased by its sight.
As you stop for camp one evening, you notice that an old man in poor clothing has made camp at the same place. The man offers to tell you a hadith he has if you can spare him some bread.
It is just an old man...
You listen carefully to the old man's hadith.\n

You have arrived in the city of al-Quds, home of the Haram esh-Sharif. But spending time in the city has been quite eye-opening. Here there are men of all sorts of different creeds. In your inn, the theological talkings of a Jewish rabbi and Christian theologian catches your ear.
The people of the book share the same God as us, no? Let us discuss...
If only they saw the only way to revere the Greatest.

You have arrived in the city of al-Quds in all of its wonder. The marvelous hustle and bustle of the city is almost overwhelming, as men and women of every creed and color walk the streets around you. Shocking you back into reality is a young girl shaking your leg. She explains she is without family, and any money helps.
I am nobility, you commoner swine! Unhand me at once!

You have spent quite some time in The Holy City of many great prophets of the God Almighty, making small talk with local aristocracy, and the time has come for you to fulfill the purpose of this pilgrimage. Dismounting a carriage, the hustle and bustle of Ancient City seemed to give way to the tranquility of mosque splendid floral patterns above you. An old man in black robes greets you, his clothing the hallmark of the local mufti of al-Quds. He bows respectfully. "Come," ushering you to join him in the midday prayer. As you step through its hallowed doors, you make way to the common praying area. All men are equal before God.
I bow my head in prayer.
Walking back through the familiar gates of my castle, I can't help but feel fulfilled. I have travelled across the land, and returned a changed man. Before Allah, all men are indeed equal.
There is no god but Allah, and Mohammad is his messenger!

You have arrived in the city of Al Madinah in all of its wonder. The marvelous hustle and bustle of the city is almost overwhelming, as men and women of every creed and color walk the streets around you. Suddenly knocking you out of contemplation is the cry of a streetside vendor with a strong Ivri accent, a peculiar scroll in his hands
What a magnificent piece! How much does it cost?
The poets of my court can do better.

You have arrived in the city of Al Madinah, City of the Prophet. As you approach the hallowed grounds, a bookish merchant glances up from behind a small stand. "Traveller! Come forth and browse my wares, the finest the old-world can offer."
That Quran must be ancient! A wondrous addition to my collection.
One does not need such frivolous relics to praise God.

You did not know quite what to expect when setting off on this grand journey, but stillness of Al-Baqi' was a certainly a surprise to you. It was no opulent display or mosque, simply a ground for where the dead now reside. Wandering through the markers said to be the final resting places of the Prophet's Family and Companions, I found myself contemplating the many great sacrifices of Muhammad (SAWS) surrounded by dozens of other pilgrims. As the world drifted further away a voice catches you from a distance. "You must be the [Root.GetTitle] of [Root.PrimaryTitle.GetName]," it calls to me. "Tell me, how do your people of [Root.Capital.GetName] follow the example of Muhammad..."
You answer to the best of your ability...
Walking back through the familiar gates of my castle, I can't help but feel fulfilled. I have travelled across the land, and returned a changed man. Before Allah, all men are indeed equal.
There is no god but Allah, and Mohammad is his messenger!

You have arrived in the city of Damascus, the gem of Syria. You walk through the Hamidiyeh souk, taking in all of its wonder. The marvelous hustle and bustle of the city is almost overwhelming, as men and women of every creed and color walk the famed neighborhoods, who’s doors and the events behind them are objects of legends. Suddenly knocking you out of contemplation is the cry of a vendor with a strong Shami accent, a gleaming sword in his hands.
What a magnificent sword! How much does it cost?
The swordsmiths of my court can do better.

ou have arrived in the city of Damascus, City of the Umayyad Caliphs. As you approach the great and ancient mosque, a robust merchant glances up from behind a small stand near the entrance of the massive Souk. "Traveller! Come forth and browse my wares, the finest in all Sham."
These designs are remarkable, perhaps more than those of the tribes of Turks.
One does not need these distracting patterns to praise God.

As you make your way through the bustling streets of Dimashq, the Athan sounds loudly, calling the faithful to prayer in the mosque. You make your way to pray alongside the other congregates. The Imam of Dimashq heading the prayer walks between the great pillars that hold the renovated dome. After the group prayer, he gives a khutbah, lamenting the great sacrifice of faith that all Muslims commit in the name of the One God, ending his lecture with a reminder to be always just.
May our sacrifices not be in vain.
Walking back through the familiar gates of my castle, I can't help but feel fulfilled. I have travelled across the land, and returned a changed man. Before Allah, all men are indeed equal.
There is no god but Allah, and Mohammad is his messenger!

Ashura commemorates the martyrdom of Hussayn ibn Ali, grandson of the Prophet, in a battle against the tyrannical Caliph Yazid on the plains of Karbala. Ashura is one of the most important holy days in Shia Islam, and its commemmoration among the faithful has survived until the present day.

The month of Muharram approaches - and with it, the solemn reminder of Ashura. The revolution of the third Imam, Hussayn, Alayhi Salam, will not be forgotten and will not go in vain. The struggle on Karbala's plain has ignited a flame that will forever remain!

The anniversary of the first day of the battle in Karbala has arrived, and with it, mourners in black flock the streets. As you watch a Taziya reenactment of the battle, you contemplate to yourself the virtue of righteous resistance. The Imam was truly brave to fight against the tyrant of his time.
Death with dignity is better than life with humiliation.
Better to live and fight another day, in my opinion.

Soon after the events at Karbala, a curious tradition of self-flagellation, or Tatbir, grew among some more zealous Shi'a. A theological debate has broken out before you, as scholars argue whether or not Tatbir is permissible - self-damage is usually considered haram, but some stubbornly adhere to the tradition.
I will join the mourners myself!
Tatbir is a problematic practice, and so I must ban it.

On this ninth day, several prominent events occurred - the Tyrant's army besieged the Imam and his companions in Karbala, and preparations for battle were made. Many of the faithful go to Mosques and engage in charity - perhaps you should, as well.
Make it so - distribute alms to the poor.

The tenth day of Muharram is here, and commemoration reaches a high point. On this day, the Imam, most of his family, and all of his companions were martyred by the forces of The Tyrant. Though the sacrifice at Karbala happened long ago, its lessons are learned from even to this day. Your thoughts are interrupted by a large shout, as the crowd chants "Ya Hussayn!"
Every day is Ashura, every land is Karbala.

It has been forty days since the commemoration of Ashura. Traditionally, many would make a pilgrimage to the shrine of the Imam, but as this is unfeasible, many of the devout choose to fast on this day in final commemoration.
I do not think that is necessary.
I cannot fast - I am at war!.
Unfortunately, war has come to your realm in the middle of Ashura. All commemmorations must cease immediately.
Voted on by their skill and prestige as a military commander, the successor of the realm will be voted on by the council and the ruler.

The Ghazwa form of government is built upon the tenets of holy war and conquest. Although loosely based on feudalism, Ghazi rulers are able to hold temple holdings and can keep their vassal levies raised for as long as they would like. If you switch from a Muslim faith, your government type will switch to Feudal.

The Sublime Diwan government represents the establishment of a great Muslim empire. The Diwan is a powerful council of advisors who advise the Sultan, representing both the standing military and the imperial bureaucracy. Most of the governors and vassals of realms are appointed by the Sultan and his council rather than being passed down within a noble dynasty. If you switch from a Muslim faith, your government type will switch to Feudal or Imperial depending on Rank.
Based off ancient customs, powerful leaders are voted among a quorum of their family whose interests are varied and sometimes petty but ultimately serves to enrich the family clan and their realm.

In the Ibadi Tradition, the Imamate represents the supreme spiritual and secular authority of an Muslim Community but unlike Sunni or Shia concepts of the Caliph and Madhi, are not predicated on the line of descent of the Prophet and the Quraysh Tribe, instead relying on an Imam's role and capabilities in understanding fiqh (Islamic Juriprudence) and defending ones community through military prowess. As such a paramount Imam must be the exemplifier of these qualities lest they incur the scorn of their community for not upholding their sacred duty. If one were to break this sacred duty, they may be replace by a much more capable Imam...
Voted on by their skill and prestige as a military commander and a learnt scholar of fiqh, the successor of the realm will be voted on by the council and the ruler.
Perhaps an excellent way to show devotion to my faith would be to visit one of its holy sites.
Perhaps an excellent time for you to conduct the Hajj to Makkah and perform the circuit around the Ka'bah.
If you wish to delve further into the mystic nature of Batin, perhaps it would be best that you connect with an Alevi Mystic and join thier rituals.
Call your Imams to begin reconciling the differences of your fellow brother and form a more harmonious union, Ahlus-Sunnah wal'Jamaah.

The mysteries of Tasawwuf and the "Inward Dimension" to the Devotion to Allah have been of great interest to you, that perhaps joining one of the many sufi orders could help you understand these mystical connections as a Pious Muslim.
Commission a tawiz, a small amulet of luck that brings protection from the unseen world.

I have decided to commission a tawiz, a lucky amulet that will offer me protection from djinns, demons, and the unseen world in general. As such, I shall wear it close to my heart when I will go on hajj. Though it would normally be a minor trinket that any Muslim should have the funds for, I am a [Root.GetTitle] and as such may afford more than a trinket.
You will receive your commissioned tawiz soon.
After some wait, I have finally received my tawiz, and I can see it was worth every coin! The artifact is beautifully engraved with verses from the Quran, and it shall protect me faithfully.
I shall wear it close to my heart!

After some wait, I have finally received my tawiz, and it is precisely what I asked for, no more, no less. While nothing exceptional, it is engraved with Quranic verses shall still protect me faithfully.
I shall wear it close to my heart!

After some wait, I have finally received my tawiz, and all I can say is that it is a disappointment. Though the craftsmanship is nothing to sneer at, the verses inscribed on it were ill-chosen, and I have been informed they may be considered shirk...
I shall wear it close to my heart still.
Join one of several Naqshbandi brotherhoods.

As a Naqshbandi ruler, I may choose to join one of the three main Naqshbandi jamiats, or brotherhoods. But which shall I pick, Iskenderpasha, Ismailagha or Mujaddidi? I should keep in mind my choice may be disliked - or approved - by other Naqshbandis.
You will be able to choose a new Jamia.
One may choose to join a new Naqshbandi brotherhood, but only once per lifetime.

As a Naqshbandi ruler, I may choose once to change which of the three main Naqshbandi jamiats, or brotherhoods, I belong to. But which shall I pick? I should keep in mind my choice may be disliked - or approved - by other Naqshbandis.
On second thoughts, my current jamia is fine.
Brittle to the touch, this Quran has survived hundreds of years, its origins pre-Event.
This prayer mat is finely crafted, with the precision of pre-Event fabrication.
Call a Great Council of Imams to rectify theological conflicts...
